q1.value: The Impact of Negative Affectivity on the Working Memory Performance

q2.value: Julia Haberstroh, Cindy Beier, Maria Bellebaum, Jonas Nikolai Karneboge, Wiebke Schulze

q3.value:
This is a project of an ExPra- group at the Department of Psychology at the University of Siegen, Germany (2019- 2020, supervising lecturer of this research group is Prof. Dr. Julia Haberstroh). This ExPra subgroup deals with the impact of negative affectivity on the working memory performance, especially the numerical working memory for medical information. In the current time everyone can share their opinion on the Internet, on any topic. The sharing of non-scientific content can be dangerous if these opinions influence other people and lead to negative affectivity. As the debates about certain drugs, especially vaccines, become louder and louder, we see high relevance in the study of whether negative affectivity in medical information seeking has an impact on working memory performance regarding medical information.
We want to induce negative affectivity through reading blog posts with dramatic or negative content regarding vaccination. In addition, the experimental group receives neutral medical information as a package leaflet. The control group only receives the neutral information. Finally, questions about side effects are to be answered.

q4.value: People with situationally induced negative affect (mood) show a reduced working memory performance, compared to persons without affect induction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (affectivity) and 2 levels (negative affect, neutral/ positive affect)

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups (control group/ experimental group). We use for data collection the open source web tool 'Lime Survey' (https://www.limesurvey.org/de/). The program automatically randomly assigns the participants to the two conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through 'Sona' (a website for students by the University of Siegen, where students can register for participation in studies), Social Media (Facebook, WhatsApp) and E- mail. The Participation is voluntary and participants will not be paid. Students from the Psychology department of the University of Siegen will get test person hours (0,5 hour). Participants must be at least 18 years old and they must not have an acute neurological or mental illness. 24 hours before participation the participants must not have consumed alcohol or other drugs.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 172 participants.

q14.value:
We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .90 power to detect an effect size of .45 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.
The effect size of .45 is based on a meta- analysis by Bar-Haim et al. (2007).

Bar-Haim Y., Lamy D., Pergamin L., Bakermans-Kranenburg M. J., Van IJzendoorn M. H. (2007). Threat-related attentional bias in anxious and nonanxious individuals: a meta-analytic study. Psychol. Bull. 133, 1–24

q15.value: We will stop our data collection at a number of 200 test subjects. Otherwise the data collection will run automatically until 31/3/2020, 23:59.

question.value:
Reading texts and blog posts that are written dramatically and negatively induces negative affects such as fear and anger in people, compared to neutral texts and we will manipulate the affectivity (mood) of the paticipants. The two levels of this categorial variable are: negative affectivity, neutral/ positive affectivity
We will check the manipulation with the items "Upset", "Afraid" and "Irritable" from the "Positive and Negative Affect Schedule" (PANAS) by Watson et al. (1988).

Example: "Please rate how you feel at the moment. You have the possibility to choose between five gradations"
Answer on a scale: "Very Slightly or not at all", "A little", "Moderately", "Quite a bit", "Extremely"

The Manipulation is successful if the gradation "A little" (or higher) has been selected for at least one of the three items.

The single outcome variable will be the numerical working memory performance for medical information about a real and common vaccine, especially about the side effects.
We will measure this by asking participants different questions about side effect of the vaccination/ the vaccine. Based on the studies of Synayey et. al (2015) and Peters et. al (2014), we have formulated our items as follows:

Example 1: "What do you think, how many people out of 10,000 people taking this medication will get stomach pain?"

Example 2: "What do you think, what is the percentage (%) of people who take this drug and get stomach pain?"

Example 3: "What do you think, how often people who take this medicine get stomach pain?"

Participants select the answer from 5 possible answers (for example: "nobody", "<10 people", "<100 people", "<1000 people", "<1000 people").

We will count the right answers per person from the questionnaire for capturing the working memory performance.
Correct answers are those given in the neutral and scientifically proven package leaflet. Wrong answers are options that are mentioned in the blog post or not mentioned at all.

We will use a two- sample t- test, because the test uses the mean values of two independent samples to check how the mean values of two populations relate to each other.
One two- sample t- test to check the affectivity of the experimental group compared to the affectivity of the control group (manipulation check). Another two- sample t- test to check the working memory (wm) performance of the experimental group compared to the wm performance of the control group (Hypothesis).

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the t- tests suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: Participants who do not complete the study will be excluded from the analyses. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If the subject does not complete the study, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to working memory performance. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demografic variables (age, gender) and the primary outcome measures of the working memory.

attributes.title: The role of national identity in collective pro-environmental action

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: The role of national identity in collective pro-environmental action: Preregistered analyses for the revision process

other.value: Not applicable. All the analyses we aim to pursue are described above.

sample.value: In our initial submission, 13,942 participants completed the measures used to inform profile membership. Given the longitudinal nature of these preregistered analyses, we expect some attrition across our dependent variables (wave-to-wave attrition for our longitudinal data set is around 80%).

analyses.value:
To investigate our hypotheses longitudinally, we will first need to create measures of residualized change for each of our dependent variables (due to limitations to our analytic approach, we are unable to conduct a standard cross-lagged model). To these ends, we will begin by conducting separate regressions for each dependent variable whereby we regress the outcome onto itself at an earlier assessment (and save the residuals). Specifically, these Time 9 measures will be regressed onto their corresponding Time 7 measures: (a) satisfaction with the environment, (b) belief in climate change, (c) belief in the anthropogenic roots to climate change, and (d) concern about climate change. Likewise, the following two Time 9 measures will be regressed on their corresponding Time 6 measures: (a) willingness to sacrifice for the environment and (b) making sacrifices for the environment. Finally, the Time 10 measure of support for the regulation of carbon emissions will be regressed onto the corresponding Time 6 measure, and the Time 10 measure of support for the subsidisation of public transport will be regressed onto the corresponding Time 5 measure of this construct.  Thus, we will conduct eight separate regressions to obtain residualized change scores that account for prior levels of the given variable. These residualized change scores will then be used as dependent variables in a subsequent set of analyses whereby we implement a distal three-step approach in Mplus version 8.4. All dependent variables will be labelled DCON and will be predicted based on participants’ most likely profile membership (relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile).

This analytical approach will allow us to examine the extent to which the five profiles is associated with changes in the dependent variables. Similar to findings obtained in our original article, we hypothesise that membership in the Isolationist, Local Egalitarian, Ethno-Nationalist, and Global Egalitarian profiles would forecast increases in the following four environmental attitudes relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile. One main limitation of this approach is that we are unable to test for bidirectional associations as the items that informed the profiles were only included at Time 7.

outliers.value: Given our analytic plan, list-wise deletion will be independently applied to each set of analyses. No other exclusion criteria will be used.

dependent.value:
Satisfaction with the Environment. Participants were asked to rate their level of satisfaction regarding several aspects of their lives and New Zealand (e.g., “Your standard of living”, “Your health”). Included in the list was the item, “The quality of New Zealand’s natural environment”, which was rated by participants on an 11-point Likert type scale from 0 (completely dissatisfied) to 10 (completely satisfied), with a midpoint of 5 signifying ‘somewhat satisfied’.

Climate Change Belief and Concern. Three items were used to assess participants’ beliefs in the reality and human basis of climate change (see Milfont, Milojev, Greaves, & Sibley, 2015), as well as climate change concern. The items were: “Climate change is real”, “Climate change is caused by humans”, and “I am deeply concerned about climate change”. Participants rated these items on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Private-Sphere Environmentalism. We used two items from Liu and Sibley (2012) to assess willingness to make sacrifices for the environment and having actually made sacrifices for the environment. The items were included at Time 9 of the NZAVS (hence, a slight attrition in sample size for the analyses that included these items): “Are you willing to make sacrifices to your standard of living (e.g., accept higher prices, drive less, conserve energy) in order to protect the environment?” and “Have you made sacrifices to your standard of living (e.g., accepted higher prices, driven less, conserved energy) in order to protect the environment?”. Participants responded to these items on a 7-point Likert type scale from 1 (definitely no) to 7 (definitely yes), with a midpoint of 4 signifying ‘maybe’.

Public-Sphere Environmentalism. We used two items developed by the NZAVS team to assess non-activist behaviour in the public sphere involving support or acceptance of environmental policies (Stern, 2000). Participants were asked to rate the level of agreement to the statement “The New Zealand government should be involved in regulating carbon emissions” on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The second item was part of a list of actual or proposed policy changes and initiatives, and participants were asked to rate their level of opposition or support to “Government subsidy of public transport” on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly support). These items were included at Time 6 (2014) and Time 5 (2013) of the NZAVS, respectively. Measurements of these variables were thus taken one year, and two years, before the other measures analysed in this study.

conditions.value: Not applicable. Our study is based on a nationally representative longitudinal panel study.

hypothesis.value:
In an initial set of exploratory analyses submitted for publication at Journal of Environmental Psychology (manuscript code: JEVP_2019_540), we identified five distinct forms of national identity. Notably, four of these five profiles (comprising 89% of the sample) viewed a “clean-and-green” attitude as central to being a “true” New Zealander, whereas an Anti-Egalitarian profile viewed this attitude as less relevant to national identity. During the review process, our reviewers asked us to theorize about potential longitudinal associations between profile membership and subsequent environmental attitudes and behaviours. Accordingly, we outline our predictions for the analyses we will pursue during the revision process below (note that we have NOT conducted any of these analyses at this point in time).

Because pro-environmental identities foster corresponding attitudes (see Clayton & Opotow, 2003), we predicted that membership in the Isolationist, Local Egalitarian, Ethno-Nationalist, and Global Egalitarian profiles would forecast increases in the following four environmental attitudes relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile: (a) satisfaction with the environment, (b) belief in climate change, (c) belief in the anthropogenic roots to climate change, and (d) concern about climate change. Also, because identities informed by pro-environmentalism foster actual pro-environmental behaviours (e.g., van der Werff, Steg, & Keizer, 2013), membership in the four profiles valuing environmentalism should forecast increases in these four behaviours relative to Anti-Egalitarians: (a) willingness to sacrifice for the environment, (b) making sacrifices for the environment, (c) support for regulating carbon emissions, and (d) support for the subsidisation of public transport. Because membership in the Global Egalitarian profile was associated with the highest levels of endorsement of these attitudes and behaviours in the cross-sectional analyses described in our initial submission, we expect the differences between Anti-Egalitarians and Global Egalitarians to be particularly pronounced. We do not, however, expect a consistent pattern of differences between the four national identity profiles characterized by high levels of pro-environmental attitudes.

Given the longitudinal nature of these preregistered analyses, we expect some attrition across our dependent variables (wave-to-wave attrition for our longitudinal data set is around 80%).
registration_responses.analyses:
To investigate our hypotheses longitudinally, we will first need to create measures of residualized change for each of our dependent variables (due to limitations to our analytic approach, we are unable to conduct a standard cross-lagged model). To these ends, we will begin by conducting separate regressions for each dependent variable whereby we regress the outcome onto itself at an earlier assessment (and save the residuals). Specifically, these Time 9 measures will be regressed onto their corresponding Time 7 measures: (a) satisfaction with the environment, (b) belief in climate change, (c) belief in the anthropogenic roots to climate change, and (d) concern about climate change. Likewise, the following two Time 9 measures will be regressed on their corresponding Time 6 measures: (a) willingness to sacrifice for the environment and (b) making sacrifices for the environment. Finally, the Time 10 measure of support for the regulation of carbon emissions will be regressed onto the corresponding Time 6 measure, and the Time 10 measure of support for the subsidisation of public transport will be regressed onto the corresponding Time 5 measure of this construct.  Thus, we will conduct eight separate regressions to obtain residualized change scores that account for prior levels of the given variable. These residualized change scores will then be used as dependent variables in a subsequent set of analyses whereby we implement a distal three-step approach in Mplus version 8.4. All dependent variables will be labelled DCON and will be predicted based on participants’ most likely profile membership (relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile).

This analytical approach will allow us to examine the extent to which the five profiles is associated with changes in the dependent variables. Similar to findings obtained in our original article, we hypothesise that membership in the Isolationist, Local Egalitarian, Ethno-Nationalist, and Global Egalitarian profiles would forecast increases in the following four environmental attitudes relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile. One main limitation of this approach is that we are unable to test for bidirectional associations as the items that informed the profiles were only included at Time 7.
registration_responses.outliers: Given our analytic plan, list-wise deletion will be independently applied to each set of analyses. No other exclusion criteria will be used.
registration_responses.dependent:
Satisfaction with the Environment. Participants were asked to rate their level of satisfaction regarding several aspects of their lives and New Zealand (e.g., “Your standard of living”, “Your health”). Included in the list was the item, “The quality of New Zealand’s natural environment”, which was rated by participants on an 11-point Likert type scale from 0 (completely dissatisfied) to 10 (completely satisfied), with a midpoint of 5 signifying ‘somewhat satisfied’.

Climate Change Belief and Concern. Three items were used to assess participants’ beliefs in the reality and human basis of climate change (see Milfont, Milojev, Greaves, & Sibley, 2015), as well as climate change concern. The items were: “Climate change is real”, “Climate change is caused by humans”, and “I am deeply concerned about climate change”. Participants rated these items on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Private-Sphere Environmentalism. We used two items from Liu and Sibley (2012) to assess willingness to make sacrifices for the environment and having actually made sacrifices for the environment. The items were included at Time 9 of the NZAVS (hence, a slight attrition in sample size for the analyses that included these items): “Are you willing to make sacrifices to your standard of living (e.g., accept higher prices, drive less, conserve energy) in order to protect the environment?” and “Have you made sacrifices to your standard of living (e.g., accepted higher prices, driven less, conserved energy) in order to protect the environment?”. Participants responded to these items on a 7-point Likert type scale from 1 (definitely no) to 7 (definitely yes), with a midpoint of 4 signifying ‘maybe’.

Public-Sphere Environmentalism. We used two items developed by the NZAVS team to assess non-activist behaviour in the public sphere involving support or acceptance of environmental policies (Stern, 2000). Participants were asked to rate the level of agreement to the statement “The New Zealand government should be involved in regulating carbon emissions” on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The second item was part of a list of actual or proposed policy changes and initiatives, and participants were asked to rate their level of opposition or support to “Government subsidy of public transport” on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly support). These items were included at Time 6 (2014) and Time 5 (2013) of the NZAVS, respectively. Measurements of these variables were thus taken one year, and two years, before the other measures analysed in this study.
registration_responses.conditions: Not applicable. Our study is based on a nationally representative longitudinal panel study.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In an initial set of exploratory analyses submitted for publication at Journal of Environmental Psychology (manuscript code: JEVP_2019_540), we identified five distinct forms of national identity. Notably, four of these five profiles (comprising 89% of the sample) viewed a “clean-and-green” attitude as central to being a “true” New Zealander, whereas an Anti-Egalitarian profile viewed this attitude as less relevant to national identity. During the review process, our reviewers asked us to theorize about potential longitudinal associations between profile membership and subsequent environmental attitudes and behaviours. Accordingly, we outline our predictions for the analyses we will pursue during the revision process below (note that we have NOT conducted any of these analyses at this point in time).

Because pro-environmental identities foster corresponding attitudes (see Clayton & Opotow, 2003), we predicted that membership in the Isolationist, Local Egalitarian, Ethno-Nationalist, and Global Egalitarian profiles would forecast increases in the following four environmental attitudes relative to the Anti-Egalitarian profile: (a) satisfaction with the environment, (b) belief in climate change, (c) belief in the anthropogenic roots to climate change, and (d) concern about climate change. Also, because identities informed by pro-environmentalism foster actual pro-environmental behaviours (e.g., van der Werff, Steg, & Keizer, 2013), membership in the four profiles valuing environmentalism should forecast increases in these four behaviours relative to Anti-Egalitarians: (a) willingness to sacrifice for the environment, (b) making sacrifices for the environment, (c) support for regulating carbon emissions, and (d) support for the subsidisation of public transport. Because membership in the Global Egalitarian profile was associated with the highest levels of endorsement of these attitudes and behaviours in the cross-sectional analyses described in our initial submission, we expect the differences between Anti-Egalitarians and Global Egalitarians to be particularly pronounced. We do not, however, expect a consistent pattern of differences between the four national identity profiles characterized by high levels of pro-environmental attitudes.

attributes.title: Perceived Criminality of Black Job Applicants: Why Ban the Box Isn't Enough

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Perceived Criminality of Black Job Applicants: Why Ban the Box Isn't Enough. 

Study description: The objective of this experiment is to investigate rates of callback and perceived hire-ability for Black job applicants for low-wage jobs under different cases of Ban the Box adoption: no-box (Ban the Box adopted) conditions, box-unchecked conditions, and box-checked conditions. We will also study participants’ facial representations of each type of applicant—Black no-box, Black box-unchecked, and Black box-checked —and evaluate perceived stereotypicality, criminality, and other descriptives of these representations.

sample.value: There will be at least 50 participants per condition for a total of 150 participants for the in-lab portion of the study. There will also be at least 100 independent raters for each. Total n = 350 participants.

analyses.value: We will separately analyze the different effects between conditions on hiring rates. We will also separately analyze the different ratings, by condition, of the composite faces created through face categorization/reverse correlation. We will cary out a logistic regression for Study 1A for callback rates (due to the binary variable: Yes or No). We will also create a composite "hire-ability" score for predicted success and trust of the applicant, then carry out 1-way ANOVAs by condition to compare hire-ability scores between conditions. To investigate facial representations as a mediating factor, we will also factor in the relationship between ratings of the faces created from reverse correlation and perceived hire-ability of those faces.

outliers.value: We will exclude people with scores 3 SDs away from the mean. We will also exclude people who won’t provide quality responses (who answer "No" to our data quality agreement.)

dependent.value: Key dependent variables are callback rates measured by whether or not participants choose to call job applicants back for an interview and perceived hire-ability measured by predicted success and trust of the job applicant, mediated by facial representations of the job applicants measured through a face categorization and reverse correlation task (in which independent raters will evaluate the composite faces of each job applicant in terms of darkness, stereotypically, etc.).

conditions.value: There will be 3 conditions: Black applicant x No-box (box banned), Black applicant x box checked (criminal record), and Black applicant x box unchecked (no criminal record).

hypothesis.value:
Main question(s): What are the psychological mechanisms behind the increased racial discrimination that occurs when "the box"--the box that asks about previous criminal history on job applications--has been banned? What are employers’ representations of the average Black applicant with no college education, and how are these representations related to perceived criminality? 
Hypotheses: We hypothesize that callback rates for job applicants will be most similar between Black no-box and Black box-checked conditions. We also predict that facial representations of Black applicants in the absence of a box will be rated as darker, more stereotypically Black, and more criminal than Black applicants with the box un-checked, as potential employers may rely on broad ideas regarding the racial makeup of the criminal justice system when information is limited.

attributes.title: Physical Activity and Exercise for Older People Living with HIV: Protocol for a Scoping Review

q1.value: Physical Activity and Exercise for Older People Living with HIV: A protocol for a scoping review.

q3.value: Older people living with HIV (OPLWH) are expected to live longer in the era of antiretroviral treatment, but at the same time, they are at risk for developing various health complications as a consequence of a life with the infection, exposure to medications that carry their own toxicity and side effects, as well as the natural effects of aging on the immune system.The purpose of this study is to map out empirical evidence on the effects of physical activity and exercise in OPLWH.

q4.value: Physical activity and exercise  can be used as an effective rehabilitative tool in OPLWH.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping review method will be guided by the framework proposed by the Joanna Briggs Institute guidelines. Literature searches will be conducted in the following electronic databases (from inception onwards): PubMed/MEDLINE, Cochrane Library and Google Scholar. Peer-reviewed journal papers will be included if they are written in English, involved human participants aged 50 years and older with HIV, and described a measure for physical, mental or functional status of physical activity/exercise and/or the recommendations in OPLWH.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Quantitative, qualitative and mixed-method studies will be included in order to consider different aspects of measuring the effects of physical activity and exercise (e.g. quality of life, functional status, activities of daily living). The reviewers will screen all citations and full-text articles. We will abstract data, organize them into themes and sub-themes, summarize them and report the results using a narrative synthesis. The study methodological quality (or bias) will be appraised using a mixed-method appraisal tool.

q13.value: The sample will include all peer reviewed studies from around the world.

question.value: The findings gathered in this review protocol will provide an overview of the research together with than an assessment of the quality of individual studies. The authors will produce a narrative report which will summarize the extracted data around the following outcomes: region of study, physical activity outcomes in HIV, as well as exercise rehabilitation prescription for OPLWH. The results will be described in relation to the research question and sub-questions in the context of the overall study purpose. It will also be depicted in the final write-up using a thematic approach that allows for flexibility in the capturing of data, because it may be possible for the review to yield unknown concepts. Gap identification will detect areas, such as countries that lack data on rehabilitation outcomes for OPLWH.

A scoping review is often used to map the concepts underpinning a research area as well as the main sources and types of evidence that is available. The authors will produce a narrative report which will summarize the extracted data around the following outcomes: region of study, physical activity outcomes in HIV, as well as exercise rehabilitation prescription for OPLWH.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
Have any data been collected for this study already?

No, no data have been collected for this study yet. 
This study will be conducted in a combined data collection with the reception year cohort recruited for the preregistered project “Young children's counting of parts and collections”: osf.io/xg2ey
Data has been collected for preschool cohort of that project. This data will however not be used to test the hypotheses proposed in the study preregistered here.

sample.value: Data will be collected with the reception year sub-sample of project A. For that project the pre-registered sample size was 40 useable datasets. Children who fail to complete all tasks will be replaced.

analyses.value:
We will calculate a hierarchical linear regression model in order to test the predictions made under our proposed counting rule overgeneralization account versus the pure object bias account. We will predict children’s numeracy scores in three steps.
1.	General control variables: Age & counting mistakes
2.	Object bias variables: object bias & inhibition
3.	Non-Object counting mistakes: object-based counting of parts & object-based counting of collections
In line with both theoretical accounts, we expect that significant additional variance in children’s numeracy scores is explained in step 2. In order to support the object bias theory of individuation, this step needs to explain significant variance. No additional variance being explained in step 2 is only compatible with the counting principle overgeneralization account. Under the object bias theory of individuation, no additional variance should be explained in step 3.  In contrast, according to the predictions of the counting principle overgeneralization account, object-based counting of collections should be related to general numeracy beyond all control variables and while also accounting for the object-based counting of parts. We would expect significant additional variance to be explained in step 3.
Significance will be evaluated in a NHST framework with an alpha level of 5%.

dependent.value:
Numeracy: Children’s general numeracy skills will be measured by the PENS-B (Purpura et al., 2015). The task has 24 items which will be solved in order. A three-in-a-row ceiling rule will be applied. A child scores either correct or incorrect on each item and the total score will be number of correct items (ranging from 0-24). 

Age: Children’s exact age as time passed between their date of birth and the testing date.

Inhibition: We will use the inhibition subset of the NEPSY-II test battery, administered within the standard time limit for 5-year-olds. More specifically, we will use raw total errors as a measure of inhibition.

Variables from the non-object counting tasks:
Those tasks will be administered as pre-registered in project A. We will however use different scores to address the specific hypothesis of this study. Please, see osf.io/xg2ey for a detailed description of the tasks and the scoring.

Counting mistakes: We will use children’s counting mistakes on the farm-animal and fruits task as a control variable. The scoring of counting mistakes for each task will be according to the scoring scheme preregistered for osf.io/xg2ey

Object bias: Before the counting task, children will be asked to name the six collections that later need to be counted. Their naming is scored either as correct, object-based or incorrect. This variable will be the sum of object-based responses when naming collections and hence will range from 0-6.

Object-based counting of parts: Total number of object-based counting mistakes on questions C, D & E on both non-object counting tasks. Scoring according to the preregistered rules on osf.io/xg2ey.

Object-based counting of collections: Total number of object-based counting mistakes on questions F, G & H on both non-object counting tasks. Scoring according to the preregistered rules on osf.io/xg2ey.

conditions.value: All children will be asked to perform all tasks in the same order (Non-object counting, numeracy, inhibition). However, the order of the two non-object counting tasks will be counterbalanced.

hypothesis.value:
Young children frequently make mistakes when they are asked to count things that are not single discrete physical objects. When asked to count collections of objects or object parts, children would often count each individual object instead. It has been previously hypothesized that these mistakes are a result of children’s bias for individuating objects based on spatio-temporal independent units (Brooks, Pogue & Barner, 2011; Shipley & Shepperson, 1990, Wagner & Carey 2001). 
In our own previous work, we found evidence for two important additions to this theory. Firstly, we demonstrated that children who correctly individuate and represent collections as a unit still prevalently make the above-mentioned counting mistakes. Secondly, we showed that the above-mentioned counting mistakes are related to children’s general number knowledge. These two findings supported our hypothesis that the counting mistakes are not solely a symptom of children’s innate biases to represent spatio-temporally independent units but are inherently tied to children’s understanding of number and counting. We hypothesized that beyond object-biases in individuation children’s mistakes when counting parts and collections are an expression of their overgeneralization of the one-to-one counting principle and lack of understanding that abstract units are equally countable. In summary, we suggest that our findings in previous studies are best explained by counting principle overgeneralization and that the link between non-single object counting and early numeracy is not completely accounted for by the object-bias theory of individuation.
In the proposed study we aim to test these two competing accounts based on their explanatory value for the connection between children’s general number knowledge and their mistakes when counting parts and collections of objects. 
The object-bias theory of individuation predicts that children have a strong initial tendency to individuate the units for counting based on their spatio-temporal independence. Neither parts of objects nor collections should be counted correctly when only an individuation based on single physical objects is available. Counting object-based instead of counting nameable object parts or collections should under this account be completely explained by children’s object bias and their inability to inhibit this object bias when counting. We would hence expect that inhibition skills as a common covariate explains the relationship between children’s numeracy and their object-based counting mistakes for both object parts and object collections. In short, under this account object-based counting mistakes should not be related to numeracy once we control for inhibition.
The counting principle overgeneralization account that we proposed in our earlier studies makes a distinguishable prediction on the relationship between children’s numeracy, their object-based counting mistakes and inhibition skills. Under this account we assume that some children form correct representations of the units to be counted and that their counting mistakes are a result of their overgeneralization of the one-to-one correspondence principle in counting and their limited application of the abstraction principle. Our previous studies found that many children can correctly represents units for object collections. If there was an overgeneralization of counting principles at play, then children’s tendency to “touch each and count” would not lead them to make mistakes when counting correctly represented object parts (because if they have a representation of ears as objects, then touch each and counting leads to a correct count). The counting rule overgeneralization should, however, lead them to incorrectly count objects instead of collections even when they can correctly represent the collections as a unit (even when correctly representing kinds of animals as [horses; cows], touching each and count leads to an object based counting mistake). Hence, under this account we should find that children’s mistakes when counting collections are related to their general numeracy above and beyond their object bias and inhibition skills. We would expect this relationship, because of how under this account children’s understanding of the application of number is inherently tied to their counting behavior for non-single objects.

q3.value:
There are two considerations in fairness decision-making. One can be referred to as fairness considerations (i.e., the pure altruism to be fair), which can be indicated by the Dictator Game. The other can be referred to as strategy considerations (i.e., being fairly for the sake of avoiding being punished for unfair behaviors), which can be indicated by the Dictator and Ultimatum Game.
The present study planed to investigate how competitiveness between participants and their task partner affect individuals' fairness decision-making, and how competitiveness affects participants' fairness and strategy considerations.

q4.value:
H1: Proposers of Ultimatum and Dictator Game will give a lower offer when they are in the competitiveness condition compared to the control condition. (which means competitiveness can decrease fairness considerations.)
H2: The offer difference between Ultimatum Game and Dictator Game is more significant in the competitiveness condition than in the control condition. (which means competitiveness can increase strategy considerations)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: The present study adopted a double-blind design.

question.value: The present study adopted a 2 (Competition: competitiveness vs. control) * 2(Games: DG vs. UG) between-subject design, with given offers as a dependent variable. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four conditions.

q9.value: All of the conditions will be randomized. Participants wil be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. The Ultimatum and Dictator Game adopt a one-trial task; thus, there is no randomization within the experiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from a university in China. 
Participants will be given course credit for agreeing to participate. 10% of the participants will be selected randomly and be paid an extra money reward due to their actual decision-making outcomes (average 40 RMB each person).
The present study will be conducted online in an online experiment platform LABVANCED during the period from 03/02/2020 to 13/02/2020. The experiment program is completed now and can be available at https://www.labvanced.com/player.html?id=6953.

q13.value:
Our target sample size is 183 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to around 220, assuming that not all will complete the total task.
The samples will be assigned to one of four conditions averagely.

q14.value: We used G*power 3.0 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to calculate the sample size. The effect size η2 from previous fairness decision-making researches ranges from 1.0 to 1.5. Therefore 183 sample sizes are required to reach enough statistics power (1-β > 0.95) at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data when the sample size is above 220.

question.value:
We will manipulate the competitiveness between participants and their game partner, and manipulate the game type.
Competitiveness has two levels: competitiveness condition vs. control condition.
Game type has two levels: Ultimatum Game vs. Dictator Game.

The dependent variable is the offer given by participants to partner in each game. In the task, participants need to decide how to divide a sum of 100 RMB between them and their partner.
We also record the manipulation check variable of competitiveness perceived by participants. We will measure this by asking participants, 'I feel that the partner has competitiveness relationship with me', 'The partner makes me feel competitiveness pressure' and 'I feel that the partner is a competitor' on a 7-point scale (1 = lowest, 7 = highest).
The covariates are Social orientation value (SVO) and Socioeconomic Status (SES), which will be measured by the SVO scale by Lange, Otten, De Bruin and Joireman (1997), and ladder scale by Adler, Epel, Castellazzo and Ickovics (2000).
Not applicable.

We will use the independent two-tailed t-test (competitiveness vs. control) to take the manipulation check, comparing the difference of perceived competitiveness between competitiveness and control conditions.
We will use a  2 (competitiveness vs. control) X 2 (Ultimatum Game vs. Dictator Game) between-subject ANOVA  to analyze our results, with SES and SVO as covariates.
We will use a linear regression model to test the relationship between perceived competitiveness and given offers of UG proposers, with competitiveness as an independent variable, offer as a dependent variable, and SES and SVO as control variables.

q21.value:
We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA, the post hoc test and the regression model suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. 
The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.
We will use two tailed tests for each of the analyses.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded if they have identical responses or fail to respond to any of the questions. In addition, those who indicate that they did not understand the regulation of the Ultimatum and Dictator Game will be excluded.
Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: The incomplete or missing data will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that reaction times may be related to fairness decision-making. Therefore, we will look for relationships between reaction times and offers in the Ultimatum and Dictator Game. We will also look for the interactive effect between reaction times and perceived competitiveness.

q3.value: In a previous paper, we found large individual differences in object-based attentional selection (Pilz et al., 2012). Here, we will use a similar letter-discrimination paradigm as in the previous paper to investigate whether the observed individual differences in object-based attention for horizontal objects are based on individual differences in the temporal aspects of attentional selection. Therefore, we systematically change the interval between a cue and a target to determine individual differences in object- and space- based attention in different cue-target intervals. We will also investigate individual differences in the underlying rhythmic patterns of visual target detection, i.e., temporal dynamics of object- and space-based effects  (Fiebelkorn et al., 2013).

q4.value:
The cue-target interval at which maximal object- and space-based effects can be observed differs on an individual basis.
The rhythmic pattern of visual target-detection within and between objects differs on an individual basis.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Design with two within-subject factors: cue-target intervals (50 - 600ms, with steps of 10ms) and target locations (valid, invalid-same and invalid-different)

q9.value: The trial order will be randomized for each participant individually across all blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: We have finished data collection, but data will not be accessed and analyzed before the preregistration of the study.

question.value:
Young adults as participants were recruited via the SONA practicum pool. SONA credits were provided for participants. Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal visual acuity, which was tested using an ETDRS chart.
Testing ended on February 7th, 2020.
Participants with a visual acuity below 0.8 will be excluded from further data analysis.

q13.value: Our sample size was 45 in total plus two participants who quit before completing the experiment.

q15.value: We will stop data collection once the target number of 45 participants is reached, or at the end of February 7th, 2020.

question.value: We manipulated two within-subject factors: cue-target intervals with 56 levels (50 - 600ms, with steps of 10ms, i.e., 50ms, 60ms, 70ms, ... ..., 560ms, 570ms, 580ms, 590ms, 600ms) and target locations with three levels. The three levels of the factor target locations are valid(target and cue appear in the same location), invalid-same(target and cue appear in the different locations but the same object) and invalid-different(target and cue appear in the different locations and different objects).

The outcome variable will be the response time (RT) and error rate of each participant. We will assess the timecourse of visual target-detection for space- and object-based effects by calculating accuracy and RT within 50ms bins, starting at 50ms, which will be shifted forward by 10ms, similar to Fiebelkorn et al., 2013.
In addition, we will record the strengths and time-points of the maximum space- and object-based effects for each participant.
We will also transform the data to the frequency domain (fourier transform) and compute the maximum frequency for space- and object-based effects similar to Fiebelkorn et al., 2013.

1) Space-based effects will be calculated by comparing the means on valid trials and invalid trials for each time point. Object-based effects will be calculated by comparing the means on invalid-same trials and invalid-different trials for each time point. T-tests will be used to calculate whether the cueing effects are greater than zero for each time point.

2) We will use a similar percentile bootstrap method as in the previous paper (Pilz et al., 2012) to investigate individual differences in object-based effects for each time point. For each subject, space-based effects will be calculated by comparing the bootstrapped means on valid trials and invalid trials. object-based effects will be calculated by comparing the bootstrapped means on invalid-same trials and invalid-different trials. Then the 2.5 and 97.5 percentiles of the bootstrapped cueing effects will be used to estimate the 95% confidence intervals for space- and object-based effects for each time point. 

3) We will use a similar method as in Fiebelkorn et al., (2013) to investigate the periodicity of space- and object-based effects. The fast Fourier transform will be used to convert the behavioral time-series data into the frequency domain. We will then determine the frequencies at which space- and object-based attentional sampling occurs. We will further determine the cross-conditional phase-relationships at those frequencies for each participant by using the complex FFT output.

q20.value: We will use the fast Fourier transform (FFT) to convert the behavioral time-series data into the frequency domain to measure periodicity in space- and object-based effects.

q21.value: We will use the standard p＜.05 criteria (after corrections for multiple comparisons) .

q22.value: RTs of less than 150 ms will be excluded as anticipatory responses, and false alarm RTs will not be analyzed.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete all the blocks, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: In Fiebelkorn et al., (2013), cross-correlational phase-relationships seem to differ largely between participants. This might be due to individual differences in periodicity of space-and object-based effects. To investigate this in more detail, we will determine the maximum frequencies for space and object-based effects for each participant individually, as well as the related cross-conditional phase relationships. We will use similar methods as the ones described above.
